The is the inverse function of the sine. Therefore the composition
function $$f:\,x\mapsto \arcsin(\sin{x})$$ is the identity map
$x\mapsto x$ on the interval $[-\frac{\pi}{2},\,\frac{\pi}{2}]$. On this
interval, the inner function $\sin$ function $\arcsin$ ( the angle
corresponding the sine value) and the whole composition correspondingly
grows from $-\frac{\pi}{2}$ to $\frac{\pi}{2}$. On the next equally long
interval $[\frac{\pi}{2},\,\frac{3\pi}{2}]$, when the inner function
decreases from 1 to $-1$, the composition thus decreases from
$\frac{\pi}{2}$ to $-\frac{\pi}{2}$, evidently again linearly. We have
now run through a interval $[-\frac{\pi}{2},\,\frac{3\pi}{2}]$ of the
inner function and the composition $f$ and obtained a wedge-formed
portion ($\wedge$) of the graph. Because of the periodicity, the whole
graph of $f$ consists of such successive wedges and thus looks like a
saw . The [*triangular-wave function*]{} is continuous. Its derivative
(away from the $\frac{\pi}{2}+n\pi,\, n\in\mathbb{Z}$) is a .
